explanation: 1) isasciidigit: The loop controlling expression directly calls isasciidigit(str[i]) and the initial if also calls isasciidigit(str[0]). To decide whether the controlling expression is potentially invariant (or whether it has side effects that change state across iterations) we must see the actual definition/prototype/macro of isasciidigit. It could be a function, a macro that expands to a constant, or a macro that reads/writes global state — each possibility affects whether the controlling expression is truly variant and whether evaluating it conforms to MISRA’s prohibition.\n\n2) UINT64_MAX: Although not part of the do-while controlling expression itself, the overflow checks in the loop body use UINT64_MAX and can force an early return. Knowing the exact macro/constant (and that it is indeed a compile-time constant) is required to reason whether the loop can iterate more than once in practice (e.g., if the overflow condition is always true/false for all inputs), which interacts with the effective behavior of the controlling expression for MISRA’s invariant-expression analysis.
